Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: I will tell you of William Wallace.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: Historians from England will say I am a liar. But history is written by those who have hung heroes.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: The King of Scotland had died without a son, and the king of England, a cruel pagan known as Edward the Longshanks, claimed the throne for himself. Scotlands nobles fought him, and fought each other, over the crown. So Longshanks invited them to talks of truce. No weapons, one page only.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: Among the farmers of that shire was Malcolm Wallace, a commoner, with his own lands and two sons: John...

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: ...and William.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Told ya to stay.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I finished my chores. Where we goin'?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: MacAndrews'. He was supposed to visit when the truce was over.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Stay here.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: MacAndrews!... MacAndrews!?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: MacAndrews.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: William! Get out of here!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Why would MacAndrews make so many scarecrows?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: R -- real!!!... Ahhhhhgggg!...

Speaker: father
Dialogue: William! William!

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Murderin' English bastards.

Speaker: ghoul
Dialogue: Will--iam...!

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Wallace is right! We fight 'em!

Speaker: macclannough
Dialogue: Every nobleman who had any will to fight was at that meeting.

Speaker: malcolm wallace
Dialogue: So it's up to us! We show them we won't lie down to be their slaves!

Speaker: macclannough
Dialogue: We can't beat an army, not with the fifty farmers we can raise!

Speaker: malcolm wallace
Dialogue: We don't have to beat 'em, just fight 'em. To show 'em we're not dogs, but men.

Speaker: malcolm wallace
Dialogue: They have a camp here. We attack them at sunset tomorrow. Give us all night to run home.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: William, you're staying here.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I can fight.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Aye. But it's our wits that make us men. I love ya, boy. You stay.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: They're coming!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: How many?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Three, maybe more!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Armed?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: They're English soldiers, ain't they?

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: With your father and brother gone, they'll kill us and burn the farm!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: It's up to us, Hamish!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Not yet! Here he comes, be ready!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Wanna stay with me tonight?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I wanna have supper waitin'.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: We'll get those English pigs tomorrow.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Aye, we'll get 'em.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: William... Come down here, lad.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: ...Restare in pacem eternis, Amen.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: You must be the relative of the deceased... William, this is your Uncle Argyle.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: You were wise to hurry.

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Someone dead from this household?

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: We just had a funeral, isn't that what it means in England as well?

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: What it means in England -- and in Scotland too -- is that rebels have forfeited their lands. We were ambushed last night. But the Scots dragged their dead away.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: My brother and nephew perished two days ago, when their hay cart turned over.

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Then we'll just have a peek at the wounds.  Dig 'em up!

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: They've been sanctified and buried in the holy rites of God's church, and any hand that disturbs them now takes on eternal damnation. So please -- do it.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Funeral's over. Go home.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Not that spoon, that one's for soup. Dip away from you. And don't slurp.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: We'll sleep here tonight. You'll come home with me. We'll let the house, and the lands too; plenty of willing neighbors.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I don't want to leave.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Didn't want your father to die either, did ya? But it happened.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Did the priest say anything about the Resurrection? Or was it all about Judgment?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: It was in Latin, sir.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Non loquis Latinum? You don't speak Latin? We have to fix that, won't we?  ...It was Malcolm's favorite.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Good night, Uncle.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: "The Lord bless thee and keep thee..."

Speaker: william
Dialogue: What are they doing?

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Saying goodbye in their own way -- in outlawed tartans, with outlawed pipes, playing outlawed tunes.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Your Daddy and I, we saw our own father buried like this, dead from fighting the English.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: First learn to use this.

Speaker: argyle
Dialogue: Then I will teach you to use this.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: Twelve years later, Longshanks supervised the wedding of his eldest son, also named Edward, who would succeed him to the throne.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: As bride for his son, Longshanks had chosen a relative of his rival, the king of France.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: It was widely whispered that for the Princess to conceive, Longshanks would have to do the honors himself. That may have been what he had in mind all along.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: Having seen to his obligations to provide for a successor, Longshanks set about his fondest business -- to crush Scotland, and turn his power against France...

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Scotland! Scot-land!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: The French will grovel to anyone with strength! But how will they credit our strength when we cannot rule the whole of our own island?!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Where is my son?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Your pardon, M'lord, he asked me to come in his stead.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: I sent for him -- and the little coward send you?!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Shall I leave, M'lord?

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: If he wants his queen to rule, then you stay and learn how! I will deal with him.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Nobles are the key to the Scottish door. Grant their nobles land here in England. Give our own nobles estates in the north. Make them too greedy to oppose us.

Speaker: old advisor
Dialogue: Sire... Our nobles will be reluctant to relocate. New lands mean new taxes, and they are taxed already for our war in France.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Perhaps it's time to reinstitute an old custom. Grant them prima noctes, "First night." When any common girl inhabiting their lands is married, our lords shall have sexual rights to her on the night of her wedding. That should fetch just the kind of lords we want in Scotland.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: What is it?!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: You directed me to report to you the moment the king's conference was ended.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: So I did! And what was so important about it?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Scotland. He intends --

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: He intends to grant --

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Shut up, would you! How can I concentrate?!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: ...His majesty was quite keen that you should understand --

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: All so very boring! He wants me to learn to fight too, so let me do it!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Stop there.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Do you disapprove of Phillip?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: No, M'lord.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Look at me. I said LOOK AT ME!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Now, my flower, do you understand?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Yes. I had thought that... I was loathsome to you. Perhaps I am. If I may be excused, M'lord.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: You may.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Don't worry, m'Lady, it is my royal responsibility to breed. And I assure you, when the time comes, I shall... manage.

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: Now in Edinburgh were gathered the council of Scottish nobles...

Speaker: voice over
Dialogue: Among these was Robert, the 17th Earl of Bruce, a leading contender for the crown of Scotland.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Young Robert, we are honored --

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: My father hears that Longshanks has granted prima noctes.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Clearly meant to draw more of his supporters here.

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: The Balliol clan has endorsed the right, licking Longshanks' boots so he will support their claim to the throne. If we make a show of opposition, the commoners will favor us.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: It is too soon to step out alone. My father believes we must lull Longshanks into confidence, by neither supporting his decree nor opposing it.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: A wise plan. And how is your father? We have missed him at the council.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: He strained his leg so that it pains him to ride. But he sends his greetings -- and says that I speak for all the Bruces. And for Scotland.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Hey boy! You hunt this bird?

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: It's against the law for Scots to own bows. You shot this bird?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I hit it in the head. With a rock.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Miz MacDougal. You look well.

Speaker: farm woman
Dialogue: ...William? It's William Wallace, back home! -- Have you met my daughter?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Hamish?

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Test of manhood.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: You win.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Call it a test of soldiery, then. The English won't let us train with weapons, so we train with stones.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: The test of a soldier is not in his arm. It's here.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: No. It's here.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: A contest, then.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I still say this is no test. A catapult can throw a stone farther than a man can.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: That depends on the man.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Can you do it when it matters? As it matters in battle? Could you crush a man with that throw?

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: I could crush you like a roach.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Then do it. Come, do it.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: You'll move

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I will not.

Speaker: farmer stewart
Dialogue: That's not fair!

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: He's tired, he should get a longer run.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Brave show!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: I threw longer than last time!

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: An ox is strong, but not clever.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: An ox is stupid enough to just stand in one place.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: That's not the point.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: That is.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: A fine display, young Wallace!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Good to see you again.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: I should'a remembered the eggs.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Would you honor me with a dance?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: You've taken over your father's farm?  They say he died long ago. Fighting the English.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: He died in an accident, with my brother. Their cart turned over.

Speaker: nobleman
Dialogue: I have come to claim the right of prima noctes. As the lord of these lands, I will bless this marriage by taking the bride into my bed on the first night of her union.

Speaker: stewart
Dialogue: No, by God!

Speaker: nobleman
Dialogue: It is my noble right.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Good evening, sir. May I speak with your daughter?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Marion... Would you like to go for a ride on this fine evening?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: The boy's insane!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: It's good Scottish weather, Madam, the rain is fallin' straight down.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: She absolutely may not, she'll -- Marion!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Your father doesn't like me, does he?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: It's not you. He dislikes that you're a Wallace. He just says... the Wallaces don't seem to live for very long.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Thank you for accepting.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Thank you for inviting.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I'll invite you again, but your mother thinks I'm crazy.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You are. And I'll come again.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Marion, come in!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Marion, come in!

Speaker: macclannough
Dialogue: Young Wallace --

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Sir, I know it was strange of me to invite Marion to ride last night. I assure you, I --

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: MacClannough's daughter is another matter. We come to fetch you to a meeting.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: What kind of meeting?

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: The secret kind.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Your father was a fighter. And a patriot.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I know who my father was. I came back home to raise crops. And, God willing, a family. If I can live in peace, I will.

Speaker: macclannough
Dialogue: If you can keep your intention to stay out of the troubles, you may court my daughter. If you break your intention, I'll kill you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You've been here before?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Some nights. I have dreams. Mostly dreams I don't want. I started riding at night to fill up my mind so that when I did sleep I'd dream only of the ride and the adventure.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Did it work?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: No. You don't choose your dreams. Your dreams choose you.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I want... to marry you!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: I... accept your proposal!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I'm not just saying it!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Nor I!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: But I won't give you up to any nobleman.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: You scare me.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I don't want to scare you. I want to be yours, and you mine. Every night like this one.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: This night is too beautiful to have again.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I will be with you, like this. Forever.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: You have come to pledge, each to the other, before Almighty God.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I will love you my whole life. You and no other.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And I you. You and no other. Forever.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: Agus bhayd lauch... The Lord bless and keep thy love, now and forever.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: I trust him -- or I'd'a killed him me'self. A weddin' needs pipes.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I've missed you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Shush. It's only been a day.  And it's seemed like forever.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Tonight then.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: My parents are growing suspicious! I can't keep meeting you every night!

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Then when?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: ...Tonight!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Where are you going... lass?

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Let go.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: William!

Speaker: market women
Dialogue: Wallace Wallace! William Wallace!

Speaker: fallen soldier
Dialogue: Rebels! Help!

Speaker: village folks
Dialogue: Run, William! Run!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: ...girl.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: What girl?!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: ...on horse.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: The girl on the horse! Stop her!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: So this is the little whore he was fighting for.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Marion!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: One Scot buggers six of us? Hell to pay when that gets round.

Speaker: corporal
Dialogue: Burn the village.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: But he is free. You never catch 'em in the Highlands.

Speaker: corporal
Dialogue: Clans weave that cloth in their own patterns.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: So why is this strip concealed?  He fought for you, eh?

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: An assault on the king's soldiers is the same as assaulting the king!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Now. Let this scrapper come to me.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Don't look surprised! We knew he'd bring friends!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: No! I beg you... mercy!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Please. Mercy!

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Say Grace to God, lads. We've just seen the coming of the Messiah.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: AHHHHHHH-UHHHHHH! AHHHHHH-UHHHHHH!

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Pour it straight into the wound. I know it seems a waste of good whiskey, but indulge me.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Ah. Now that'll clear your sinuses, lads.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Well bloody Hell, look at this! Now it's nothing but a fly swatter.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: MacGregor -- from the next valley!

Speaker: macgregor
Dialogue: We heard about what was happenin'. And we don't want ya thinkin' ya can have your fun without us.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Go home. Some of us are in this, I can't help that now. But you can help yourselves. Go home.

Speaker: macgregor
Dialogue: We'll have no homes left when the English garrison at the castle comes through to burn us out.

Speaker: lord bottoms
Dialogue: Gather the horses! Align the infantry!  Ride to the Lord Governor in Stirling.

Speaker: lord bottoms
Dialogue: Stop them... Don't let... Align...

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: On your way somewhere, M'lord?

Speaker: lord bottoms
Dialogue: Murdering bloody bandit!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: My name is William Wallace. I am no bandit who hides his face... Find this man a horse.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Give him a horse.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Not this horse. That one.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Today we will spare you, and every man who has yielded. Go back to England. Tell them Scotland's daughters and her sons are yours no more. Tell them Scotland is free.

Speaker: scots
Dialogue: Wal-lace, Wal-lace, Wal-lace!...

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Scottish rebels have routed Lord Bottoms!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I hear. This Wallace is a bandit, nothing more.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: You weak little coward! Stand up!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: I go to France to press our rights there! I leave you to handle this little rebellion, do you understand? DO YOU?!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: And turn yourself into a man.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Get away from me!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Convene my military council!

Speaker: nicolette
Dialogue: They say this Wallace killed thirty men to avenge the death of his woman. I hope your husband goes to Scotland. Then you'll be a widow.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I wanted to please you.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: In Lanark village, the king's soldiers killed a girl. Her lover fought his way through the soldiers and killed the magistrate.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: He rebelled. He rebelled. He acted. He fought! Was it rage? Pride? Love? Whatever it was, he has more of it than I.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: You might have lied.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I'm too arrogant to lie.

Speaker: the leper
Dialogue: Under whom?

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: A commoner named William Wallace.

Speaker: the leper
Dialogue: A commoner? So no one leads Scotland?

Speaker: the leper
Dialogue: You will embrace this rebellion. Support it, from our lands in the north. I will gain English favor by condemning it and ordering it opposed from our lands in the south. Whichever way the tide runs, we will rise.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: This Wallace. He doesn't even have a knighthood. But he fights with passion, and he is clever. He inspires men.

Speaker: the leper
Dialogue: You admire him. Uncompromising men are easy to admire. He has courage. So does a dog. But you must understand this: Edward Longshanks is the most ruthless king ever to sit on the throne of England, and none of us, and nothing of Scotland, will survive unless we are as ruthless, more ruthless, than he.

Speaker: the leper
Dialogue: Press your case to the nobles. They will choose who rules Scotland.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Ah, William... I am so sorry.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: I'll wait... back there.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Hamish, I... thank...

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: What're ya doin'?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Thinking.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Does it hurt?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: What do we do when Longshanks sends his whole northern army against us? They have heavy cavalry. Armored horses, that shake the very ground. They'll ride right over us.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: We make spears. A hundred spears. Fourteen feet long.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Fourteen? --

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Stand up, man, I'm not the Pope.

Speaker: faudron
Dialogue: I am Faudron! My sword is yours! And I brought you this tarta --

Speaker: sentry
Dialogue: We checked them for arms.

Speaker: faudron
Dialogue: It's your family tartan! My wife wove it with her own hands.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Thank her for me.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Him? That can't be William Wallace! I'm prettier than this man!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: All right, Father, I'll ask him!  If I risk my neck for you, will I get a chance to kill Englishmen?

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Is your Poppa a ghost -- or do you converse with God Almighty?

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: In order to find his equal, and Irishman is forced to talk to God.  The Almighty says don't change the subject, just answer the fookin' question.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Insane Irish --

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Smart enough to get a dagger past your guards, old man.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: That's my friend, Irishman. And the answer's yes. You fight for me, you kill the English.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Excellent! Stephen is my name. I'm the most wanted man on the Emerald Isle. Except I'm not on the Emerald Isle of course, more's the pity.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: A common thief.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: A patriot!

Speaker: scout
Dialogue: Scotsmen, Sire! Headed west!

Speaker: dolecroft
Dialogue: They've blundered at last! After them!

Speaker: scout
Dialogue: We're in a bog!

Speaker: dolecroft
Dialogue: Here, it's firm this way --

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Stop here and rest.

Speaker: pickering
Dialogue: Another ambush! My God! ...What about our infiltrator?

Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: He has already joined them, M'lord.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Marion! Is... is it you?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I'm dreaming.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Yes, you are. And you must wake.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I don't want to wake. I want to stay with you.

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: And I with you. But you must wake.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I need you so much! I love you!

Speaker: marion
Dialogue: Wake up, William. Wake up!

Speaker: hamish's voice
Dialogue: Wake up, William!...

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: William! Hounds!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: We must run in different directions!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: We don't split up!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: They used hounds on us in Ireland, it's the only way!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: He's right, Hamish! Campbell! Divide them and run!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Split again!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: No matter how we go, they follow. They have our scent. My scent.

Speaker: faudron
Dialogue: Run! You must not be caught!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: We can't stop!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: They've tricked us.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: What's the crazy man saying, Lord?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: The dogs have a scent. My scent. Someone must have given it to them.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Who would do such a thing?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: handler
Dialogue: Be ready! We have them!

Speaker: lord pickering
Dialogue: Damnation! Damnation!

Speaker: lord pickering
Dialogue: After him! Get them going again!

Speaker: handler
Dialogue: Their noses are drowned in new blood, they'll follow nothing now!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: I thought I was dead when ya pulled that dagger!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: No English lord would trust an Irishman!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Let's kill him anyway.

Speaker: villager
Dialogue: ...and William Wallace killed fifty men! Fifty, if it was one!

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: A hundred men! With his own sword! He cut a through the English like --

Speaker: drinker
Dialogue: -- Moses through the Red Sea! Hacked off two hundred heads!

Speaker: drinker
Dialogue: Saw it with my own eyes.

Speaker: nicolette
Dialogue: When the king returns he will bury them in those new clothes. Scotland is in chaos. Your husband is secretly sending an army north.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: How do you know this?

Speaker: nicolette
Dialogue: Last night I slept with a member of the War Council.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: He shouldn't be telling secrets in bed.

Speaker: nicolette
Dialogue: Ah, Oui! Englishmen don't know what a tongue is for.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: This Scottish rebel... Wallace? He fights to avenge a woman?

Speaker: nicolette
Dialogue: A magistrate wished to capture him, and found he had a secret lover, so he cut the girl's throat to tempt Wallace to fight -- and fight he did.

Speaker: nicolette
Dialogue: Knowing his passion for his lost love, they next plotted to take him by desecrating the graves of his father and brother and setting an ambush at the grave of his wife. He fought his way through the trap and carried her body to a secret place! Now that is romance, Oui?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: ...I wouldn't know.

Speaker: runner
Dialogue: The English are advancing an army toward Stirling!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Do the nobles rally?

Speaker: runner
Dialogue: Robert the Bruce and most of the others will not commit to war! But word has spread and Highlanders are coming down on their own, by the hundreds -- by the thousands!

Speaker: people
Dialogue: Wallace! It's William Wallace! God bless Wallace and Scotland!

Speaker: lochlan
Dialogue: It sounds like twenty thousand!

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: The scouts say it is ten.

Speaker: lochlan
Dialogue: And we have but two!

Speaker: young soldier
Dialogue: So many!

Speaker: scottish veteran
Dialogue: The nobles will negotiate. If they deal, they send us home. If not, we charge. When we are all dead and they can call themselves brave, they withdraw.

Speaker: young soldier
Dialogue: I didn't come to fight so they could own more lands that I could work for them!

Speaker: veteran
Dialogue: Nor did I. Not against these odds!

Speaker: lochlan
Dialogue: Stop! Men! Do not flee! Not now! Wait until we have negotiated!

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: They won't stop -- and who could blame them?

Speaker: young soldier
Dialogue: William Wallace?

Speaker: veteran
Dialogue: Couldn't be.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: The Almighty says this must be a fashionable fight, it's drawn the finest people.

Speaker: lochlan
Dialogue: Where is thy salute?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: For presenting yourselves on this battlefield, I give you thanks.

Speaker: lochlan
Dialogue: This is our army. To join it, you give homage.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I give homage to Scotland. And if this is your army, why does it go?

Speaker: scottish veteran
Dialogue: We didn't come to fight for them!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Sons of Scotland!... I am William Wallace!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: William Wallace is seven feet tall!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Yes, I have heard! He kills men by the hundreds! And if he were here, he would consume the English with fireballs from his eyes, and bolts of lightning from his ass!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I am William Wallace. And my enemies do not go away. I saw our good nobles hanged. My wife... I am William Wallace. And I see a whole army of my countrymen, here in defiance of tyranny. You have come to fight as free men. And free men you are! What will you do with freedom? Will you fight?

Speaker: veteran
Dialogue: Two thousand, against ten? We will run -- and live!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Yes. Fight and you may die. Run and you will live, at least awhile. And dying in your bed many years from now, would you be willing to trade all the days from this day to that, for one chance to come back here as young men, and tell our enemies that they make take our lives, but they will never take our freedom?

Speaker: veteran
Dialogue: Look! The English comes to barter with our nobles for castles and titles. And our nobles will not be in the front of the battle!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: No! They will not!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: And I will.

Speaker: scots
Dialogue: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! WAL-LACE!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Fine speech. Now what do we do?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Bring out our spearmen and set them in the field.

Speaker: cheltham
Dialogue: Mornay. Lochlan. Inverness.

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: Cheltham. This is William Wallace

Speaker: cheltham
Dialogue: Here are the King's terms. Lead this army off the field, and he will give you each estates in Yorkshire, including hereditary title, from which you will pay him an annual --

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I have an offer for you.

Speaker: cheltham
Dialogue: ...From which you will pay the King an annual duty...

Speaker: lochlan
Dialogue: You disrespect a banner of truce?!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: From his king? Absolutely. Here are Scotland's terms. Lower your flags and march straight to England, stopping at every Scottish home you pass to beg forgiveness for a hundred years of theft, rape, and murder. Do that, and your men shall live. Do it not, and every one of you will die today.

Speaker: cheltham
Dialogue: You are outmatched! You haven't even any cavalry! In two centuries no army has won without it!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I'm not finished. Before we let you leave, your commander must cross that bridge, stand before this army, put his head between his legs, and kiss his own ass.

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: I'd say that was rather less cordial that he was used to.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Be ready, and do exactly as I say.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Wish I could see the noble lord's face when he tells him.

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: Insolent bastard! Full attack! Give no quarter! And I want this Wallace's heart brought to me on a plate!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: The Lord tell me He can get me out of this mess. But He's pretty sure you're fooked.

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: Amateurs! They do not even contest us! Send across the infantry.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: M'lord, the bridge is so narrow --

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: The Scots just stand in their formations!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Steady! Hold... hold... NOW!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: FORM!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Here I am, English coward! Come get me!!

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: Press the men across!

Speaker: cheltham
Dialogue: But M'lord!

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: PRESS THEM!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Tell Mornay to ride to the flank and cross upstream. Wait! Tell him to be sure the English see him ride away!

Speaker: lochlan
Dialogue: If he waits much longer --

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Ride around and ford behind them!

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: We should not divide our forces!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Wallace says do it! And he says for you to let the English see you!

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: They shall think we run away.

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: See! Every Scot with a horse is fleeing! Hurry! Hurry!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: For Scotland!

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: Press reinforcements across!

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: He's taking the bloody bridge! The English can't get across! He's evened the odds at one stroke!

Speaker: talmadge
Dialogue: Use the archers!

Speaker: general
Dialogue: They're too close, we'll shoot out own men!

Speaker: general
Dialogue: We are still five thousand! Rally!

Speaker: scottish soldiers
Dialogue: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!

Speaker: elder
Dialogue: I knight thee Sir William Wallace.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Wal-lace, Wal-lace!!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Does anyone know his politics?

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: No. But his weight with the commoners could unbalance everything. The Balliols will kiss his ass, so we must.

Speaker: steward
Dialogue: Lords of Scotland: Sir William Wallace!

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Sir William. In the name of God, we declare and appoint thee High Protector of Scotland! And thy captains as aides decamp!

Speaker: balliol
Dialogue: Sir William!! Inasmuch as you and your captains hail from a region long known to support the Balliol clan, may we invite you to join us?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: You are Robert the Bruce.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: My father fought in support of yours.

Speaker: balliol
Dialogue: With this new success, the result of all of Scotland's efforts, now is the time to declare a king!

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: Then you are prepared to recognize our legitimate succession!

Speaker: balliol
Dialogue: You're the ones who won't support the true claim! I demand consideration of these documents!

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: Those were lies when they were written! Our documents prove absolutely that --

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Sir William! Where are you going?

Speaker: william
Dialogue: We have beaten the English! But they'll come back, because you won't stand together. There is one clan in this country -- Scotsmen. One class -- free. One price -- courage.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: But... what will you do?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I will invade England. And defeat the English on their own ground.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Invade?! That's impossible, it --

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: LISTEN TO ME! Longshanks understands this! This!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: There is a difference between us. You think the people of this country exist to provide you with position. I think your position exists to provide the people with freedom. And I go to make sure they have it.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Wait! ...I respect what you said. But remember, these men have lands, castles. Much to risk.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: And the common man who bleeds on the battlefield, does he risk less?

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: No. But from top to bottom this country has no sense of itself. Its nobles share allegiance with England and its clans war with each other. If you make enemies on both sides of the border, you'll end up dead.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: We all end up dead. It's only a question of how. And why.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I'm no coward! I want what you want! But we need the nobles.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Nobles? What does that mean -- to be noble? Your title gives you claim to the throne of our country. But men don't follow titles, they follow courage! Your arm speaks louder than your tongue. Our people know you. Noble and common, they respect you. If you would lead them toward freedom, they would follow you. And so would I.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Message from your cousin, the Prince. He says London has no more troops to send.

Speaker: governor
Dialogue: Every town in Northern England is begging for help! Where will Wallace strike first?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: I should think these smaller settlements along the border...

Speaker: rider
Dialogue: He advances!

Speaker: governor
Dialogue: To what town?

Speaker: rider
Dialogue: He comes here!

Speaker: governor
Dialogue: We will not allow a bandit to panic the greatest city in Northern England! Close off the escapes! Let no one leave!

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: The city has emptied already, Sire. Only the Scottish civilians remain.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Back! Wait for it to burn!

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: They've breached the wall!

Speaker: governor
Dialogue: Then do as I ordered.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: STOP! NOT YET! LISTEN TO ME!  They wish to frighten us! Or goad us into attacking too soon! Don't look away! LOOK!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Behold the enemy we fight! We will be more merciful than they have been. We will spare women, children, and priests. For all else, no mercy.

Speaker: phillip
Dialogue: It is not your fault! Stand up to him.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I will stand up to him, and more.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: What news of the north?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Nothing new, Majesty. We have sent riders to speed any word.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: While I am in France fighting to expand your future kingdom I learn that Stirling castle is lost, our entire northern army wiped out! And you have done nothing?!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I have ordered conscriptions...

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Wallace has sacked York!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Impossible.  How dare you bring a panicky lie.

Speaker: phillip
Dialogue: Sire! Thy own nephew! What beast could do such a thing?!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: If he can sack York, he can invade lower England.

Speaker: phillip
Dialogue: We would stop him!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Edward, who is this shitpoker who speaks to me as if I needed his advice?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: I have declared Phillip my High Counselor.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: You fight back at last!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: We must sue for a truce, and buy him off. But who will go to him? Not I. If I came under the sword of this murderer, I would end up like my nephew. And not you, the sight of my faggot son would only encourage an enemy to take over this country. So whom do I send?

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: A royal entourage comes, flying banners of truce, and the standards of Longshanks himself!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Longshanks! I have come.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I am the Princess of Wales.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Wife of Edward, the king's son?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I come as the king's servant, and with his authority.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: It's battle I want, not talk.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: But now that I am here, will you speak with a woman?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I understand that you have recently been given the rank of knight.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I have been given nothing. God makes men what they are.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Did God make you the sacker of peaceful cities? The executioner of the king's nephew, my husband's own cousin?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: York was the staging point for every invasion of my country. And that royal cousin hanged a hundred Scots, even women and children, from the city walls.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: That is not possible.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Longshanks did far worse, the last time he took a Scottish city.

Speaker: crony
Dialogue: He is a murdering bandit, he lies.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I am no bandit. And I do not lie.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Or in French if you prefer that: Certainmous et ver! Ask your king to his face, and see if his eyes can convince you of the truth.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Hamilton, leave us.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Leave us now.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Her husband's more of a queen than she is. Did you know that?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Let us talk plainly. You invade England. But you cannot complete the conquest, so far from your shelter and supply. The King proposes that you withdraw your attack. In return he grants you title, estates, and this chest with a thousand pounds of gold, which I am to pay to you personally.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: A Lordship. And gold. That I should become Judas.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Peace is made is such ways.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: SLAVES ARE MADE IN SUCH WAYS!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I understand you have suffered. I know... about your woman.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: She was my wife. We married in secret because I would not share her with an English lord. They killed her to get to me. And she was pregnant.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I've never told anyone. I don't know why I tell you -- except because you look... much like her. And someday you will be a queen, and you must open your eyes!  Tell your king that William Wallace will not be ruled. Nor will any Scot, while I live.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Sir. I leave this money, as a gift. Not from the king, but from myself. And not to you, but to the orphans of your country.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: My son's loyal wife returns, unkilled by the heathen. So he accepted our bribe.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: No. He did not.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Then why does he stay? My scouts say he has not advanced.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: He waits. For you. He says he will attack no more towns -- if you are man enough to come fight him.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: You spoke with this Wallace in private. What kind of man is he?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: ...A mindless barbarian. Not a king like you, M'lord.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: The Scottish nobles have sent him no support. His army starves. Our stall has worked, he must withdraw. You may return to your embroidery.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Humbly, M'lord.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: You brought back the money, of course?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: No. I have it to ease the suffering of the children of this war.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: This is what happens when you must send a woman. And a fool.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Forgive me, Sire. I thought that generosity might demonstrate your greatness to those you mean to rule.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: My greatness is better demonstrated with this.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: The weapon has been outlawed by the Pope himself!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: So the Scots will have none of them, will they? My armorers have already made a thousand.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: William -- French guards?

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: That is why the Pope outlawed the weapon! It makes war too terrible.

Speaker: mornay
Dialogue: How many does Longshanks have?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: A thousand.  You have made me Guardian of Scotland. So I tell you this is what we face.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: We must sue for peace.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Peace?!

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: We cannot defeat this --

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: With cavalry -- not heavy, like the English, but light, fast horsemen, like you nobles employ -- we could outmaneuver their bowmen!

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: It is suicide.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Sir William --

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: We won at Stirling and still you quibbled! We won at York and you would not support us! Then I said nothing! Now I say you are cowards!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Please, Sir William! Speak with me alone! I beg you!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: You have achieved more than anyone dreamed. But fighting these odds looks like rage, not courage. Peace offers its rewards! Has war become a habit you cannot break?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: War finds me willing. I know it won't bring back all I have lost. But it can bring what none of us have ever had -- a country of our own. For that we need a king. We need you.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I am trying.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Then tell me what a king is! Is he a man who believes only what others believe? Is he one who calculates the numbers for and against him but never weighs the strength in your own heart? There is strength in you. I see it. I know it.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: I must... consult with my father.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: And I will consult with mine.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Remember when the English turned their hounds on us? Maybe we should introduce them to our dogs.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: This... cannot be the way.

Speaker: the leper
Dialogue: You have said yourself that the nobles will not support Wallace, so how does it help us to join the side that is slaughtered?

Speaker: the leper
Dialogue: My son. Look at me. I cannot be king. You, and you alone, can rule Scotland. What I tell you, you must do -- for yourself, and for your country.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: The Bruce is not coming, William.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Mornay has come. So will the Bruce.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Stephen ready?

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Aye.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Irish troops!

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: So that's where Longshanks got his soldiers. Irishmen, willing to kill Scottish cousins for the English.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: Their families are starving, they'll feed them however they can. If you don't want to fight them --

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: No. I'll stand with you.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: They can't be that stupid to attack the schiltrons again.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: It's only a faint to shield the crossbows!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Now! Give 'em the dogs!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Now! Charge! Charge them!

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Mornay?

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: For double his lands in Scotland, and matching estates in England.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Betrayed!

Speaker: general
Dialogue: My God, and still they come!

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Use the reinforcements! But take Wallace alive!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Hamish! Ham --

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Get him away!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: A charge! Form up! Form up!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Fight me! Fight me!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: FIGHT ME!

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Son... I want to die on the ground.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: Whew. That'll clear your sinuses. Goodbye, boys.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: No. You're going to live.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: I don't think I can do without one of those... whatever it is...

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: You... were like my father...

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: ...And glad to die, like him... So you could be the men you are. All of ya.

Speaker: campbell
Dialogue: I'm a happy man.

Speaker: advisor
Dialogue: Their nobles have sworn allegiance, M'lord. Every last one.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Now we kill two birds at one stroke. We recruit from Scotland for our armies in France.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: The Scots will fight for us?

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: What choice do they have? Now they must serve us or starve.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: But if we have not caught Wallace --

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: He is gone! Finished! Dead! If he has not yet bled to death or had his throat cut for him, he will not survive the winter. It is very cold -- is it not, our flower?

Speaker: leper
Dialogue: I am the one who is rotting. But I think your face looks graver than mine.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: He was so brave. With courage alone he nearly won.

Speaker: leper
Dialogue: So more men were slaughtered uselessly!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: He broke because of me. I saw it. He lost all will to fight.

Speaker: leper
Dialogue: We must have alliance with England to prevail here. You achieved that! You saved your family, increased your lands! In time you will have all the power in Scotland!... Yet you grieve.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: In my heart I had begun to hope that he would never break.

Speaker: leper
Dialogue: All men lose heart. All betray. It is exactly why we must make the choices we make.

Speaker: people
Dialogue: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Is it true about Mornay?

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: And he rode through the window? My God.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: His legend grows! It will be worse than before!

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: You let Wallace escape your whole army. You cannot blame me for this.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Good day to you, M'Lords.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: You mock us with a smile?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I am cheerful with a plan to soothe your miseries. All of England shudders with the news of renewed rebellion.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Wallace's followers.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Wallace himself. If you wish to pretend a ghost rallies new volunteers in every Scottish town, I leave you to your hauntings. If you wish to take him, I know a way.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I have faced him. Have you?

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: Let her speak.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: He will fight you forever. But what does he fight for? Freedom first, and peace. So grant them.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: The little cow is insane --

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Grant, as you do everything else, with treachery. Offer him a truce to discuss terms, and send me to my castle at Locharmbie as your emissary. He trusts me. Pick thirty of your finest assassins for me to take along. And I will set the meeting, and the ambush.

Speaker: longshanks
Dialogue: You see, my delicate son? I have picked you a Queen.

Speaker: chief assassin
Dialogue: We came in small groups, so the rebels would not suspect.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: And you have reached Wallace's men?

Speaker: chief assassin
Dialogue: We tell the villagers, and the traitors pass it on. All that's left is for you to say where.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Thanks for the food and drink. And for bringing 'em yourselves.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: We're here to stay. We don't care to live, if we can't fight beside ya.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: There is... one thing, William. Longshanks is offering a truce. He has dispatched his daughter-in-law as his emissary, and she has sent word that she wishes to meet you -- in a barn.

Speaker: chief assassin
Dialogue: It's William Wallace, sure! And... he's given up his sword! Be ready!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: A meeting in a barn. It had to be a trap. And only you would know I would be aware of it.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: It does me good to see you.

Speaker: william
Dialogue: I am much diminished since we met.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: There will be a new shipment of supplies coming north next month. Food and weapons. They will trav --

Speaker: william
Dialogue: No. Stop. I didn't come here for that.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Then why did you come?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Why did you?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Because of the way you're looking at me now. The same way... as when we met.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I know. You looked at me... and saw her.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: You must forgive me what I feel. No man has ever looked at me as you did.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: You have... you have a husband.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I have taken vows. More than one. I've vowed faithfulness to my husband, and sworn to give him a son. And I cannot keep both promises.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: You understand. Consider, before you laugh and say no. You will never own a throne, though you deserve one. But just as the sun will rise tomorrow, some man will rule England. And what if his veins ran not with the blood of Longshanks, but with that of a true king?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I cannot love you for the sake of revenge.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: No. But can you love me for the sake of all you loved and lost? Or simply love me... because I love you?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: No one! Hurry!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: When we... did you think of her?

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Rest, William.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I rest.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Your rest is making me exhausted.

Speaker: stephen
Dialogue: Come, it'll help you sleep.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Aye. But it won't let me dream.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: May he rest in peace... You have already sealed the coffin?

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: He was a modest man.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: It will not be long before Longshanks too is encased in stone, and his crowns divided for others to wear.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Our nobles are frightened and confused... Wallace has the commoners stirred up again, from the Highland clans to the lowland villages. In another six months Christ and the Apostles could not govern this country.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Longshanks knows his son will scarcely be able to rule England, much less half of France. He needs Scotland settled, and he trusts you, after Falkirk. If you pay him homage, he will recognize you as king of Scotland. Our nobles have agreed to this as well.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: If I pay homage to another's throne, then how am I a king?

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Homage is nothing. It is the crown that matters!

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: The crown is that of Scotland. And Scotland is William Wallace.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: That is another matter. There is a price to all this, required both by Longshanks and our nobles. Pay it, and you will be our king. And we will have peace.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Sir William. We come to seek a meeting.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: You've all sworn to Longshanks.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: An oath to a liar is no oath at all. An oath to a patriot is a vow indeed. Every man of us is ready to swear loyalty to you.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: So let the council swear publicly.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: We cannot. Some scarcely believe you are alive. Other think you'll pay them Mornay's wages. We bid you to Edinburgh. Meet us at the city gates, two days from now, at sunset. Pledge us your pardon and we will unite behind you. Scotland will be one.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I will meet you, but only one way -- if Robert the Bruce is there, and puts his hand on my Bible, and swears his loyalty to Scotland.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: He has already agreed to come.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: You know it's a trap.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Probably. But we can't win alone. We know that. This is the only way.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: I don't want to be a martyr.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Nor I! I want to live! I want a home and children and peace. I've asked god for those things. But He's brought me this sword. And if He wills that I must lay it down to have what He wants for my country, then I'll do that too.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: That's just a dream, William!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: We've lived a dream together. A dream of freedom!

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Your dreams aren't about freedom! They're about Marion! You have to be a hero, because you think she sees you! Is that it?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: My dreams of Marion are gone. I killed them myself. If I knew I could live with her on the other side of death, I'd welcome it.

Speaker: hamish
Dialogue: Keep these. We're going too.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: No. One of us is enough.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: He won't come.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: He will. I know he will.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Here. And unarmed. My God, he has a brave heart.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: He is not to be harmed. I have your king's absolute promise that he will be imprisoned only!

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Now we will have peace.

Speaker: people
Dialogue: Don't look so fearsome, does he?!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Is it true? Wallace is captured?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Simply because he eluded your trap, do you think he is more than a man? My father is dying. Perhaps you should think of our coronation.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: When will his trial be?

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Wallace's? For treason there is no trial. Tomorrow he will be charged, then executed.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Longshanks promised!

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: You are surprised he would lie? Balliol was murdered in a church yesterday. You are Longshanks' new designate. You will be king.

Speaker: royal magistrate
Dialogue: William Wallace! You stand in taint of high treason.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Treason. Against whom?

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Against thy king, thou vile fool! Hast thou anything to say?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Never, in my whole life, did I swear allegiance to your king --

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: It matters not, he is thy king!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: -- while many who serve him have taken and broken his oath many times. I cannot commit treason, if I have never been his subject!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Confess, and you may receive a quick death. Deny, and you must be purified by pain. Do you confess? ...DO YOU CONFESS?!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I do not confess.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Then on the morrow, thou shalt receive they purification... And in the end, I promise you'll beg for the axe.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I am so afraid... Give me strength.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: Your Highness!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I will see the prisoner.

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: We've orders from the king --

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: The king will be dead in a month! And his son is a weakling! Who do you think will rule this kingdom? Now OPEN THIS DOOR!

Speaker: jailer
Dialogue: On your feet, you filth!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Stop! Leave me!  There is no way out of this hell! Leave me with him!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: M'lady... what kindness of you to visit a stranger.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Sir, I... come to beg you to confess all, and swear allegiance to the king, that he might show you mercy.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Will he show mercy to my country? Will he take back his soldiers, and let us rule ourselves?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Mercy... is to die quickly. Perhaps even live in the Tower. In time, who knows what can happen, if you can only live.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: If I swear to him, then everything I am is dead already.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Your people are lucky to have a princess so kind that she can grieve at the death of a stranger.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: You will die! It will be awful!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Every man dies. Not every man really lives.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Drink this! It will dull your pain.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: It will numb my wits, and I must have them all. If I'm senseless, or if I wail, then Longshanks will have broken me.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I can't bear the thought of your torture. Take it!

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I have come to beg for the life of William Wallace.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: You fancy him.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: I respect him. At worst he was a worthy enemy. Show mercy... Oh thou great king... and win the respect of your own people.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Even now, you are incapable of mercy?

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: Nor you. To you that word is as unfamiliar as love.

Speaker: edward
Dialogue: Before he lost his powers of speech, he told me his one comfort was that he would live to know Wallace was dead.

Speaker: princess
Dialogue: You see? Death comes to us all. And it comes to William Wallace. But before death comes to you, know this: your blood dies with you. A child who is not of your line grows in my belly. Your son will not sit long on the throne. I swear it.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: We will use it all before this is over. Or fall to your knees now, declare yourself the king's loyal subject, and beg his mercy, and you shall have it.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: That's it! Stretch him!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Pleasant, yes? Rise to your knees, kiss the royal emblem on my cloak, and you will feel no more.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Very well then. Rack him.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Wonderful, isn't it, that a man remains conscious through such pain. Enough?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: That... will... clear your sinuses.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: It can all end. Right now! Bliss. Peace. Just say it. Cry out. "Mercy!" Yes?... Yes?

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Mer-cy! Mer-cy! Mer-cy!

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: The prisoner wishes to say a word!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: FREEEEE-DOMMMMMM!

Speaker: english commander
Dialogue: I hope you washed your ass this mornin -- it's never been kissed by a king before.

Speaker: craig
Dialogue: Come, let's get it over with.

Speaker: robert
Dialogue: Stop.

Speaker: scots
Dialogue: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!

Speaker: wallace's voice
Dialogue: In the year of our Lord 1314, patriots of Scotland, starving and outnumbered, charged the fields of Bannockburn. They fought like warrior poets. They fought like Scotsmen. And won their freedom. Forever.

Speaker: scots
Dialogue: Wal-lace! Wal-lace! Wal-lace!
